And guess what! Gay marketers have been lying to us all along. Gay males earn, on average, <em>less</em> than straight males (lesbians more than straight females), most studies agree. This is rather different from what gay marketers have been trying to sell us for years – that “the gay community” is a “dream” or “affluent” market. </p>  <p> Use this resource to learn the truth about gay money. Especially useful for <a href="http://joeclark.org/gaymoney/journos/" title="Information for journalsits">journalists</a>.</p> </content> </entry>    <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-11-08T12:48:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-11-08T12:48:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://fantasticmanlist.wordpress.com/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:fantasticmanliszt</id> <title type="html"><cite>FANTASTIC MAN</cite> LIST</title> <content type="html">\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdThe List” is the most interesting feature of <small><cite>FANTASTIC MAN</cite></small> magazine</content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-09-22T12:48:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-09-22T12:48:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/economics/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:fagonomics-readingcompleted</id> <title type="html">The reading phase of bibliography on lesbian and gay economics now complete</title> <content type="html"> <p> I have now completed reading what I believe to be every English-language refereed article published on any topic vaguely related to lesbian and gay economics, many popular-press articles, and most books on “gay marketing.” I am writing an <em>annotated bibliography</em> on lesbian and gay economics, not just a citation list. </p>  <p> After 61 papers spanning 650 pages and about a dozen books,  the writing phase begins. </p>  </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-05-17T16:00:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-05-17T16:00:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/economics/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:fagonomics-teaser</id> <title type="html">Bibliography on lesbian and gay economics</title> <content type="html"><p> Over the next several months, I will be reading what I believe to be every English-language refereed article published on any topic vaguely related to lesbian and gay economics. </p> <div id="TFagonomics_papers-cropped.jpg-img" class="splorpist"> <img src="http://joeclark.org/economics/Fagonomics_papers-cropped.jpg" alt="Hand holding about 15 papers bound together with colored alligator clips"> </div>  <p> I’m doing this so there will be a single point of reference for anyone who wishes to confirm the oft-repeated claim that gay men earn more than straight men. According to all the reading I’ve done so far, <em>that is <strong>completely false</strong></em> and you should not be repeating that claim. Gay men do <em>not</em> earn more than straight men, the data I’ve read show. Anyone who claims otherwise has a vested interest, and is usually peddling some ill-assembled marketing materials with a sales agenda. </p>  <p> I will review and annotate every paper and book and will cross-reference them according to their findings. </p> <h2 id="wyw">While you’re waiting</h2>  <p> Start with M.V. Lee Badgett’s classic book <cite><a href="http://www.librarything.com/work/1074741/book/47165018" title="LibraryThing entry">Money, Myths and Change</a></cite>, available at many libraries and easily Amazonable. </p> </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-05-12T17:00:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-05-12T17:00:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://fawny.org/teamakers/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:teamakersarch</id> <title type="html">Tea Makers Fake Ouimet archives restored</title> <content type="html">Who\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds accusing whom of \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdcrimes,\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Alphonse Ouimet?</content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-03-13T12:30:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-03-13T12:30:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/word/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:woty</id> <title type="html">Tracking nominees for Canadian Word of the Year 2010</title> <content type="html"><p> I have a degree in linguistics and I wrote <a href="http://en-CA.org/" title="‘Organizing Our Marvellous Neighbours’">a book about Canadian spelling</a>. This does not make me an arbiter of anything, merely an informed commentator. </p>    <p> Nevertheless, people coin new words every year. What will be the new word of the year for 2010? For Canada specifically? </p>    <p> What will be the <strong>Canadian Word of the Year 2010</strong>? </p>    <p> I don’t know and I don’t get to decide. But what I’m going to do for the rest of the year is keep an ongoing list of contenders. We’re starting out with <cite>VANOC</cite>, <cite>Own the Podium</cite>, and <cite>TTC sleeper</cite>. </p> </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-03-09T12:30:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-03-09T12:30:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/ebookstandards/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:ebookala</id> <title type="html">New article on E-books at A List Apart</title> <content type="html">With any luck, the definitive article: “<a href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/ebookstandards/" title="An HTML-triumphalist view of E-books">Web Standards for E-books</a>.” </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-03-08T12:30:00-04:00</published> <updated>2010-03-08T12:30:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://en-ca.org/new/#T2010-03-08" /> <id>tag:updates,2010:epubalert</id> <title type="html">Old Wine in New Bottles Alert: ePub version of <cite>Organizing Our Marvellous Neighbours</cite> coming</title> <content type="html"> In a week or so, <cite>Organizing Our Marvellous Neighbours</cite> will be reissued in actual ePub format so you can read it on any E-book reader that isn’t a Kindle. (Yes, including the iPad, eventually.) You’ll have to buy it again, but it’ll be half price. </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2010-02-11T22:13:49-04:00</published> <updated>2010-03-02T22:14:49-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/access/webaccess/vancouver2010/"/> <id>tag:del,2010:olympism</id> <title type="html">Vancouver Olympics Web sites are inaccessible to disabled people </title> <content type="html">Even though Vancouver Olympics CEO John Furlong promised six years ago that the Games’ Web site would be accessible, it isn’t – not really, and sometimes not at all. Neither is CTVOlympics.ca. This could all have been avoided. (Now with <a href="http://joeclark.org/access/webaccess/vancouver2010/" title="Downloads">downloadable source code from the two sites</a>) </content> </entry>  <entry <updated>2010-01-08T13:33:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/access/crtc/AODA/#where-09"/> <id>tag:access,2010:Taoda-spec-donde</id> <title type="html">Where\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds the <acronym>AODA</acronym> Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities  information and communications standard?</title> <content type="html"><p>It’s on ice.</p><p> In November 2009, I asked the Ministry of Community and Social Services the following: </p>  <blockquote> <p> I am under the impression that the standard for information and communications, while ostensibly "final" and sent to the Ministry for "consideration," is actually completely stalled and nothing is happening on it. Also, either the committee was disbanded or its term ended, but in any event there is no committee in place to work on the standard if it needs that. </p>   <p> Even if these aren't the exact terms you would use, do I have that more or less correct? </p> </blockquote>  <p> I did. Their response: </p>  <blockquote> <p> Following public review, the Committee revised the standard and submitted their Final Proposed Information and Communications Standard to the Minister of Community and Social Services on May 29, 2009. This fulfilled the mandate of the Committee....  </p>  <p> The Information and Communications Standard is not law and decisions have not yet been made with respect to the Committee’s proposal.  Upon receipt of the final proposed standard, the Minister may adopt the recommendations into regulation in whole, in part or with modifications, including timelines for compliance.   <span class="grey">[...]</span>  </p>  <p class="noindent"> <ins class="ed">[Signed]</ins> Brenda Lewis<br> Director, Standards Policy and Coordination Branch<br> Accessibility Directorate of Ontario </p> </blockquote> </content> </entry>   <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2009-10-21T14:00:00-04:00</published> <updated>2009-10-26T14:00:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.openandclosed.org/docs/counteroffer"/> <id>tag:sucks,2009:T2009-bluffcalling</id> <title type="html">Bluff-calling exercise</title> <content type="html"><p> Most of the “Real Science” campaign ends today with the Project’s submission to the CRTC and <acronym title="Canadian Association of Broadcasters">CAB</acronym>. <a href="http://openandclosed.org/docs/counteroffer/" title="A counterproposal for consumer-supported, independent captioning research">We’ve made them an offer they can’t refuse.</a> </p>  <p> Thanks to all my <a href="http://captioningsucks.com/realscience/supporters/" title="Supporters">supporters</a>. I still have a few tasks to complete.  </p> </content> </entry>   <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2009-10-06T14:00:00-04:00</published> <updated>2009-10-06T14:00:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://captioningsucks.com/realscience/" /> <id>tag:sucks,2009:T2009-realscience1</id> <title type="html">The Captioning Sucks! \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdReal Science\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Campaign</title> <content type="html"><strong class="caps">CAPTIONING SUCKS!</strong> launches its <a href="http://captioningSUCKS.com/realscience/" title="The Captioning Sucks! ‘Real Science’ campaign">“Real Science” Campaign</a>, with the primary goal of submitting a counterproposal to industry. We want to carry out <em>legitimate scientific research into captioning</em>. We could use your help. </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2009-09-11T15:53:00-04:00</published> <updated>2009-09-11T15:53:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/access/crtc/consultation2009/" /> <id>tag:updated,2009:consult1</id> <title type="html">Submission to Canadian copyright consultation</title> <content type="html">My submission to the ongoing copyright consultation is all about alternate-format books, and is more or less a broadside against the CNIB. </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2009-07-21T15:53:00-04:00</published> <updated>2009-07-21T15:53:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/unwebbable" /> <id>tag:updated,2009:ala-unwebbab;le</id> <title type="html">New at A List Apart: ‘Unwebbable’</title> <content type="html">Today my article, long in gestation, appears at A List Apart: “<a href="http://www.alistapart.com/articles/unwebbable/" title="ALA: Unwebbable">Unwebbable</a>” examines how not every document can be folded and mutilated into a “Web page.” </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2009-06-02T13:00:00-04:00</published> <updated>2009-06-02T13:00:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/cranky/" /> <id>tag:updated,2009:crankylaunch</id> <title type="html">‘The Cranky Copyright Book’, my new project</title> <content type="html">Launching today is my new book project, <cite>The Cranky Copyright Book</cite>. It’s all about copyright reform <em>for creators</em>, and <a href="http://joeclark.org/cranky/contribute/" title="Contribute to ‘The Cranky Copyright Book’">I could use your help</a>. </content> One of the tasks of the <a href="http://www.mcss.gov.on.ca/mcss/english/pillars/accessibilityOntario/what/about_ado.htm" title="Accessibility Directorate of Ontario">Accessibility Directorate of Ontario</a> is the creation of <a href="http://www.mcss.gov.on.ca/mcss/english/pillars/accessibilityOntario/accesson/business/information/" title="Homepage for the standard">a standard for information and communications</a>. </p> <p> And <a href="http://joeclark.org/access/crtc/AODA/November2007/" title="Comments on AODA information and communications standard">I’ve got comments</a>. </p> </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2007-10-22T14:32:01-04:00</published> <updated>2007-10-22T14:32:01-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/micro/" /> <id>tag:post-aea,2007:T2007.10.22-revenge</id> <title type="html">Micropatronage: This time it’s <em>personal</em></title> <content type="html"><p> Last year, I began a <dfn>micropatronage</dfn> campaign to fund me while I fundraised for my research project, the <a href="http://openandclosed.org/" title="OC-Pro">Open & Closed Project</a>. Now I’m giving micropatronage another go. This time the goal is to lobby against closed-door “standards” and in favour of our own open standards, and to propose a radical new deregulation plan that would provide fro 100% accessibility. </p>  <p> This time I’m trying something new. <a href="http://joeclark.org/micro/" title="Joe Clark Micropatronage">This time <em>it’s personal</em>. Micropatronage: <span class="caps">THE REVENGE</span>.</a> </p> </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2007-10-08T16:33:00-04:00</published> <updated>2007-10-08T16:33:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/apart" /> <id>tag:post-aea,2007:T2007.10.08-notes</id> <title type="html">Speaking notes from An Event Apart available</title> <content type="html"><a href="http://joeclark.org/appearances/AEA/2007/" title="Why I Hate Online Captioning">Notes posted</a> from my presentation at An Event Apart (“Why I Hate Online Captioning”). </content> </entry>  <entry xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <author> <name>Joe Clark</name> </author> <published>2007-09-18T15:27:00-04:00</published> <updated>2007-09-18T15:27:00-04:00</updated>   <link rel="alternate" type="text/html" href="http://joeclark.org/atypi" /> <id>tag:post-atypi,2007:T2007.09.18-notes</id> <title type="html">Speaking notes from <acronym>ATypI</acronym> available</title> <content type="html">Speaking notes posted from <acronym>ATypI</acronym> (<a href="http://joeclark.org/appearances/atypi/2007/caption-subtitle/" title="Don’t show printouts to grannies and call that a test">captioning</a>;
